G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, such that the Superior Court has subject-matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2 and 9.proposition: Venue is proper in the Berkshire Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and 9 because the cause of action arose here and Defendant resides and/or has his usual place of abode here.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to the condition of the land, including conditions created by trees and vegetation on or emanating from the property.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to the condition of the land, including conditions created by trees and vegetation on or emanating from the property.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners/occupiers to all lawful visitors regarding the condition of the premises. While this concurrence excerpt focuses on concern about the treatment of trespassers, the core holding of the case (from the majority opinion) directly supports the proposition that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, which would include hazards from trees and vegetation as part of the land’s condition. The text provided does not mention trees specifically, but the general duty clearly covers conditions of land in general.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion, not the concurrence]: "We therefore hold that the distinctions between licensees and invitees should no longer be recognized in this Commonwealth, and that the occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care in all the circumstances."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to the condition of the land, including conditions created by trees and vegetation on or emanating from the property.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms that, under Massachusetts premises liability law, a property owner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors as to hazards on the land. It then holds that this same duty applies to all hazards arising from snow and ice, treating those hazards no differently from other conditions on the property. While the case’s facts involve ice, the reasoning is framed generally as to conditions on the land and the duty to lawful visitors, consistent with the proposition stated.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now discard the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, which had constituted an exception to the general rule of premises liability that a property owner owes a duty to all lawful visitors to use reasonable care to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances. … We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

Williams v. G & C Gemini, Inc., 469 Mass.raw_text: Williams v. G & C Gemini, Inc., 469 Mass. 640 (2014)
Williams v. G & C Gemini, Inc., 469 Mass.proposition: Defendant, as owner and person in control of the Property and the maple tree in question, owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to inspect, maintain, and control the tree and its limbs so as not to create an unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully using the adjacent public sidewalk.
Williams v. G & C Gemini, Inc., 469 Mass.case_name: Superintendent-Director of Assabet Valley Regional Vocational School District v. Speicher
Williams v. G & C Gemini, Inc., 469 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion in Williams v. G & C Gemini, Inc. as excerpted here concerns arbitration and the standard of review for suspensions of teachers under Massachusetts education statutes. It does not involve premises liability, landowners’ duties regarding trees, or obligations to persons using adjacent public sidewalks. Therefore, it does not address or support the proposition about a defendant’s duty to inspect and maintain a tree on property bordering a public sidewalk.
Williams v. G & C Gemini, Inc., 469 Mass.relevant_excerpt: Turning to the statute, § 42D provides that any employee who has been suspended thereunder may seek “review of the suspension.” The statute further specifies that the form of review is “arbitration,” and the “procedures” for seeking review are “set forth in [§ 42].” Section 42 contains the phrase “review of a dismissal decision,” and no one suggests that a “review” under § 42 means anything but full arbitral review of the merits of the dismissal.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently recognized that landowners must take reasonable steps to protect foreseeable persons from defects or hazards of which they know or reasonably should know, including naturally occurring conditions, when a failure to act may cause injury.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The case clearly affirms that Massachusetts landowners owe a common-law duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants, including a duty to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition and to remedy even open and obvious dangers when harm is foreseeable. However, Dos Santos does not concern or discuss naturally occurring conditions; it involves an artificial, man‑created hazardous setup (trampoline next to a shallow pool). Therefore, while it supports the general reasonable-care/foreseeability duty and the duty to remedy open and obvious dangers, it does not support the specific inclusion of naturally occurring conditions as framed in the proposition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’”}

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently recognized that landowners must take reasonable steps to protect foreseeable persons from defects or hazards of which they know or reasonably should know, including naturally occurring conditions, when a failure to act may cause injury.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The opinion reiterates the general Massachusetts rule that landowners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers they know or should know. However, the proposition adds that this duty extends to “naturally occurring conditions” and suggests a broader obligation to protect foreseeable persons from off-premises defects or hazards. Davis actually limits landowner duty with respect to adjacent public highways and declines to expand it, and it does not discuss naturally occurring conditions at all. Thus it does not support the full, specific proposition stated.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.raw_text: Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc., 45 Mass. App. Ct. 461 (1998)
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.proposition: Defendant further owed a duty to act reasonably once placed on notice—actual or constructive—of the defective condition of the tree limb.
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.case_name: Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Chapter 21E contaminated property damages case focused on statutory cost recovery and the proper measure of property damage. It does not involve personal injury, premises liability, trees, or any discussion of a duty to act reasonably upon actual or constructive notice of a defective tree limb or similar hazardous condition. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition about a defendant’s duty once on notice of a defective tree limb.
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: Because § 5 is silent as to how to measure the damages for the private right of action created by it, we look to the common law for guidance. At common law, the measure of damages to real property is dependent upon whether “the injury is permanent” or “reasonably curable by repairs.” … When the injury is permanent, the appropriate measure of damages is diminution of value… When the injury is temporary… the expense of repairs, if less than the diminished market value, is the measure of recovery.

Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248 (1957.proposition: Defendant further owed a duty to act reasonably once placed on notice—actual or constructive—of the defective condition of the tree limb.
Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248 (1957.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a state enforcement officer was a trespasser when he entered and parked on plaintiff’s land while performing his official duties. The court’s analysis focuses on statutory and common-law authority for lawful entry by public officers and explicitly holds that his entry and presence were lawful and non-trespassory. It does not address any duty to act reasonably upon notice of a defective tree limb or any analogous premises-liability duty relating to dangerous conditions; thus it does not support the stated proposition.
Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248 (1957.relevant_excerpt: “It appears from the findings of the auditor that the defendant entered the premises to investigate suspected illegal activities relating to the taking of shellfish in the vicinity, a purpose within the scope of his duties as law enforcement officer for the department of natural resources… His original entry being lawful there was nothing in his subsequent conduct which served to make him a trespasser ab initio…. The automobile in the present case was on the plaintiff’s property only temporarily and caused no damage.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s inaction and failure to remedy the hazardous condition violated his duty under Massachusetts common law negligence principles requiring the exercise of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that, under Massachusetts common-law negligence principles, the homeowner had a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm arising from the hazardous condition—here, improperly secured firearms accessible to a known violent, mentally unstable person. The opinion reverses summary judgment precisely so a jury can decide whether Kask’s failure to act to ensure proper storage breached that duty and caused the harm to the officer. This directly supports the proposition that such inaction and failure to remedy a hazardous condition can violate a duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “[W]e conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage. We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant’s inaction and failure to remedy the hazardous condition violated his duty under Massachusetts common law negligence principles requiring the exercise of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The case does not hold that the defendant’s inaction or failure to remedy a hazardous condition violated any duty; instead, the court affirms summary judgment because plaintiffs failed to prove causation and also failed to show the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition. The opinion reiterates general negligence elements but expressly notes the absence of evidence linking any property defect or failure to obtain a permit to the accident. Thus, it does not provide authority that the defendant’s inaction constituted a breach of duty under Massachusetts negligence law in these circumstances.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The record reflects that the plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them as either homeowner or general contractor, or because of any failure to warn of any purported defect on his property. … The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The injuries sustained by Plaintiff were the type of harm that reasonable care in inspecting and maintaining the tree limb was intended to prevent.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurrence states that the facts would not warrant a finding that plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. That indicates the court (including this concurring justice) did not view the plaintiff’s injuries as the type of harm reasonably foreseeable from the defendant’s conduct. Thus, the opinion does not support the proposition that the injuries were the type of harm reasonable care in inspecting and maintaining the tree limb was intended to prevent; it supports the opposite. However, the excerpt is brief and does not mention tree limbs expressly, so confidence is medium.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the view that "[t]he facts would not warrant a jurys finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardos negligence." Ante at 640-641.

Pomeroy v. Westfield, 268 Mass. 552 (192.proposition: The weather conditions on August 15, 2023, constituted a relatively normal summer thunderstorm for Massachusetts and did not amount to an unforeseeable “Act of God” or extraordinary natural event that would break the chain of causation or relieve Defendant of his duty.
Pomeroy v. Westfield, 268 Mass. 552 (192.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns specific performance of a real estate exchange contract and the plaintiff’s burden to prove ability to convey good title. It does not discuss weather, Acts of God, foreseeability, or intervening natural events affecting causation or duty. Therefore, it provides no authority for characterizing any weather conditions as a normal thunderstorm versus an unforeseeable Act of God.
Pomeroy v. Westfield, 268 Mass. 552 (192.relevant_excerpt: “Manifestly it would be inequitable to order specific performance by the defendant unless the court is satisfied that she will receive what she contracted to obtain. Proof that he could give the defendant the title which the agreement called for was an essential element in the plaintiff’s case.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all damages proximately caused by his negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other general and special damages.

Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 409 M.raw_text: Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 409 Mass. 256 (1991)
Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 409 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all damages proximately caused by his negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other general and special damages.
Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 409 M.support_reasoning: The opinion is about liability and defenses under the Massachusetts child trespasser statute and comparative negligence. It never discusses the scope or types of damages recoverable (medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, etc.), nor does it articulate a general rule that a negligent defendant is liable for all proximately caused damages. The judgment ultimately bars any recovery because plaintiff’s comparative negligence exceeded defendant’s, so the case does not serve as authority for the proposition about the range of recoverable damages in a negligence action.
Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 409 M.relevant_excerpt: “The jury… found that the plaintiff was comparatively negligent. The jury determined that the plaintiff was 75% at fault, while MEC was 25% at fault. Thus, the plaintiff was barred, under the comparative negligence statute, G. L. c. 231, § 85 (1988 ed.), from recovering any damages from MEC.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks prejudgment interest on her damages at the statutory rate from the date of commencement of this action, as allowed by G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
